keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting a higher toll of 48.
Floods and landslides have affected five Mexican states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Breakdown of fatalities: 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and around 320,000 people have suffered power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The flooding is attributed to the remnants of Tropical Storm Raymond and Hurricane Priscilla, which brought heavy rainfall to western Mexico.
President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military to assist in rescue and aid distribution, stating, 'We will not leave anyone without support.'
Photos from the military show evacuations using life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high waters.
Mexico has experienced unusually heavy rains this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential flooding across central and southeastern Mexico, driven by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Storm Raymond, has resulted in at least 44 deaths and dozens of people missing. The affected states include Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi, with fatalities distributed as 18, 16, 9, 1, and 0 respectively. Mexico’s El Universal reports a higher death toll of 48. Around 320,000 people have lost power, and 16,000 homes have been damaged. The government has mobilized the military for rescue and aid, with images showing evacuations using life rafts and rescue workers navigating flooded areas. The event is linked to an unusual year of heavy rainfall, including Mexico City’s rainiest June in over two decades.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
